              - bundle exec rake

      caches:
        bundler: vendor/bundle
        pip: ~/.cache/pip

          image: postgres
          environment:
            POSTGRES_DB: 'myapp_test'
            POSTGRES_USER: 'root'
            POSTGRES_PASSWORD: 'test_user_password'

    Lets take this moment to breakdown what exactly our pipelines file is doing.     Provisioning SSL certificates on your Server

    If you handle sensitive information on your web app, like processing payments or entering passwords, then itâ€™s important you protect your users by making sure your website is secure using SSL. Itâ€™s basically like sending a letter, but making sure you put it in an envelope and seal it up before firing it off. With search engines now favouring SSL sites over others, itâ€™s a good way to boost your ranking and ensure youâ€™re protected.

    What isÂ SSL?

    SSL, or Secure Sockets Layer, is a protocol that ensures a secure connection between the client and server so that information can be sent and received securely. This works by encrypting the data using a key-pair, a private key only accessible on server and a public key accessible to everyone. The message is encrypted and sent to the sever, with the public key, if the public key matches the private key, the data is decrypted and processed by the server accordingly. You can tell if youâ€™re SSL secure by the green padlock on your web browser, if it says something like â€œSecure Connectionâ€ youâ€™re good. Also the URL prefix would be https://â€¦ as opposed toÂ http://â€¦

    Setup

    Pretty much most service providers, like GoDaddy, NameCheap, RapidSSL etcâ€¦ provide an easy process to buy a certificate. Once purchased, youâ€™ll need to generate a CSR (certificate signing request), it doesnâ€™t matter where this is done, it doesnâ€™t need to be done on the same server that you wish to install the certificate on. There are two ways to do this, through the terminal using openssl or (if youâ€™re on a Mac) through the KeyChain Access application.

    Using theÂ Terminal

    $ openssl req -new -newkey rsa:2048 -nodes -keyout yourdomain.key -out yourdomain.csr

    This command will prompt you to go through a little creation wizard, as highlighted below.

    Youâ€™ll be asked to enter a few details as well as choosing a password for the keypair.     File Types

    .pem

    This is the most common format and can have other suffixâ€™s, includingÂ .pem,Â .crt,Â .key andÂ .cer. Youâ€™ll know itâ€™s in aÂ .pem format if the file is readable in a text editor and starts withâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€ŠBEGIN CERTIFICATEâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€Š. These types of certificates are used with Apache, Nginx and similarÂ servers.

    .der

    This is a binary form of theÂ .pem certificate. It can have the suffixÂ .der andÂ .cer and is typically used on the Java platform.

    .p7b/PKCS#7

    These types of certificates are also readable in a text editor, they start withâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€ŠBEGIN PCKSâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€Šand end withâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€ŠEND PCKS7â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€”â€Š. They can contain certificates or chain certificates but canâ€™t contain the private key, which will need to be in a separate file. These are supported on platforms like Windows andÂ Tomcat.

    .pfx/PCKS#12

    This type of certificate file stores the certificate, any additional certificates and the private key in one binary, encryptable file. This is typically used on Windows platforms.

    If you find yourself with the wrong format, for whatever reason, there is a way to convert them. For more information, head over here and follow the simple instructions.

    Using KeychainÂ Access

    Do a quick spotlight search for Keychain Access and open up the application, itâ€™ll look something like this. Youâ€™ll then want to head to the menu and navigate to the option Request a Certificate From a Certificate Authorityâ€¦

    This will bring up the following Certificate Assistant, where youâ€™ll be asked to enter a few details. Ensure you choose the option Save toÂ disk.

    Once hitting Continue, youâ€™ll be asked where you want to save yourÂ .csr file, after that yourÂ .csr will be generated.     Thatâ€™s it really, depending on your type of server and configuration installation of the certificate will vary, but itâ€™s usually quite straightforward.

    Free SSL Certificates

    AWS, Heroku, Azure all provide free SSL certificates for certain services.     This service offers a free, automated and open certificate authority. It works by running a certificate management agent on your web server.
